question_feedback.student_choice: A hub, because it creates a single collision domain where all devices compete for bandwidth
question_feedback.correct_answer: A hub, because it creates a single collision domain where all devices compete for bandwidth
question_feedback.analysis: Excellent understanding of collision domains and how hubs operate at the physical layer
question_feedback.explanation: You correctly identified that hubs create a single collision domain where all connected devices share the total bandwidth. When one device transmits a large file, it monopolizes the shared medium, causing all other devices to wait and experience slowdown. This is a fundamental difference between hubs (shared bandwidth) and switches (dedicated bandwidth per port).

question_feedback.student_choice: When you need to route packets between different IP subnets
question_feedback.correct_answer: When you need to connect two different network segments and have budget constraints for a simple, low-port-count solution
question_feedback.analysis: You confused the functions of Layer 2 (bridges) and Layer 3 (routers) devices. This suggests mixing up OSI layer functionalities
question_feedback.explanation: Bridges operate at Layer 2 (Data Link) and work with MAC addresses and frames, not IP addresses and packets. Routing between IP subnets is a Layer 3 function performed by routers. Bridges are used today primarily for simple, cost-effective connections between two network segments when you don't need the advanced features of a switch.

question_feedback.student_choice: Router - it will examine the destination IP address and determine the next hop
question_feedback.correct_answer: Router - it will examine the destination IP address and determine the next hop
question_feedback.analysis: Strong understanding of router functionality and IP address analysis for path determination
question_feedback.explanation: You correctly identified that routers operate at Layer 3 and make forwarding decisions based on IP addresses. Since the communication is between different networks (192.168.1.x to 203.45.67.x), a router is essential to determine the path and forward packets to the appropriate next hop toward the destination.

question_feedback.student_choice: A switch drops unknown frames while a hub forwards them
question_feedback.correct_answer: A switch floods unknown frames to all ports except the source, while a hub repeats all signals to all ports
question_feedback.analysis: You misunderstood how switches handle unknown unicast traffic. This indicates a gap in understanding switch learning behavior
question_feedback.explanation: Switches don't drop unknown frames - they flood them to all ports except the source port to ensure delivery while learning MAC addresses. This is different from hubs, which simply repeat all electrical signals to every port regardless of the frame type. The key difference is that switches make intelligent decisions and maintain MAC address tables, while hubs are purely physical layer repeaters.

question_feedback.student_choice: A gateway, because it can translate between different protocol stacks
question_feedback.correct_answer: A gateway, because it can translate between different protocol stacks
question_feedback.analysis: Excellent understanding of gateway functionality and protocol translation requirements
question_feedback.explanation: You correctly identified that gateways can translate between completely different protocol stacks. IPX and TCP/IP are different network layer protocols with different addressing schemes and packet formats, requiring protocol translation that only a gateway can provide. Routers, switches, and bridges work within the same protocol family and cannot perform this type of protocol conversion.
